Stevens, Timothy J. (LNG-MBC) wrote:

> 	Many of my tests wind up being nearly as long as the class being
> tested... I have no desire to double the size of my code with tests. Plus,
> tests that exist within the classes they are testing will ultimately get
> compiled along with the classes, increasing the size of your distributions
> needlessly.


You're not doubling the size of your code - you're doubling the size of 
the source files, by eliminating the separate test files. I think that's 
a non-argument, or as an argument, comes dangerously close to "I'm too 
busy writing code to write tests".

It shouldn't increase the size of your distribution, either - just don't 
jar the inner test classes. As long as your classes don't call *into* 
the test classes (and they should never do that), then it's fine.


> 
> 	I go with the separate-yet-parallel directory structure route, and
> tend to make most methods protected rather than private to allow them to be
> tested. I'm sure someone will chime in shortly for logic surrounding only
> testing public methods.

That's actually what i do, too. But i'm reasonably comfortable accessing 
my private methods indirectly.
